title: Multi-scale, Correlative Investigation of Thermo-mechanical Fatigue in SAC Solder Balls
content: The lifetime of micro- and power-electronic devices is largely dependent on the lifetime of solder joints, which ensure electrical and thermal conductivity from the chip to the printed circuit board. However, electronic devices may experience a large temperature range during their service life, which introduces mechanical stresses into these solder joints due to misfits in thermal expansion coefficients (CTE) between the various parts in the multi-material device [1–3]. When a device is thermally cycled, these stresses cause fatigue in the solder, which ultimately leads to fatigue cracking of the solder in the vicinity of the chip- and PCB-interfaces [3, 4], impairing the solder’s electrical and thermal conductivity [4] and ultimately resulting in failure of the device. In recent years, efforts have been made to improve the fatigue resistance of Sn – 3.0 wt.% Ag – 0.5 wt.% Cu (SAC305) solder alloys, which are commonly used in micro- and power-electronics. The predominant fatigue mechanism in SAC305 solders is intergranular fatigue cracking [1, 3]. One approach to enhance fatigue strength in SAC305 is adding Bi to the alloy, which acts as a solid solution strengthener (Bi content ≤ 2.5 wt.% [5]), increasing its yield strength and hence delaying recrystallisation and subsequent intergranular cracking [6].
